info.title: Example of an OpenAPI document different schemas

get.description: Example of a JSON object with an array of tags using items schema.

200.description: An object containing an array of tags

get.description: Example of a JSON object with a circular reference.
Example of a JSON object with multiple levels.

200.description: Example of a deeply nested structure

get.description: Example of a JSON object with a string.
Example of a JSON object with a number.
Example of a JSON object with a boolean.
Example of a JSON object that can be null.

get.summary: Get a tuple array with prefixItems
get.description: Example of a JSON array with prefixItems defining a tuple structure.

200.description: A tuple array with fixed positions

get.summary: Get a mixed array with prefixItems and items
get.description: Example of a JSON array with both prefixItems and items schemas.

200.description: An array with fixed positions followed by additional items

post.summary: Test complex schema with oneOf and anyOf
post.description: Example of a complex request and response schema using oneOf and anyOf.

200.description: Complex response with oneOf and anyOf schemas

get.summary: Get user role using oneOf constants
get.description: Example endpoint demonstrating a property 'role' constrained by oneOf constants.

200.description: An object with a role property using oneOf constants

role.description: User role constrained by oneOf constants

TagsObject.description: An object containing arrays of tags and related metadata for categorization and organization

tags.description: A collection of string tags used for categorizing content or items

metadata.description: Additional information related to the tags including supplementary data

numbers.description: Numeric values associated with each tag for ranking or other quantitative purposes

items.description: A number associated with the tag

Parent.description: A parent object that demonstrates circular references by containing a child that references back to its parent

id.description: Unique identifier for the parent object

child.description: Reference to a child object that belongs to this parent

Child.description: A child object that references its parent, creating a circular reference structure

id.description: Unique identifier for the child object

parent.description: Reference back to the parent object that owns this child

Level1.description: The top level of a deeply nested structure demonstrating how OpenAPI can handle complex hierarchical data

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 1 object

level2.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 2)

Level2.description: The second level in a deeply nested structure, continuing the hierarchy from Level1

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 2 object

level3.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 3)

Level3.description: The third level in the nested hierarchy, demonstrating *deep nesting* capabilities

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 3 object

level4.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 4)

Level4.description: The fourth level in the nested structure, continuing to demonstrate schema reference chaining

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 4 object

level5.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 5)

Level5.description: The fifth level in the nested structure, showing how **deeply nested** references can be handled

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 5 object

level6.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 6)

Level6.description: The sixth level in the nested structure, continuing the deep reference chain

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 6 object

level7.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 7)

Level7.description: The seventh level in the nested structure, demonstrating how OpenAPI can handle complex data hierarchies

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 7 object

level8.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 8)

Level8.description: The eighth level in the nested structure, showing the flexibility of schema references

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 8 object

level9.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 9)

Level9.description: The ninth level in the nested structure, continuing the *deep reference chain*

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 9 object

level10.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 10)

Level10.description: The tenth level in the nested structure, marking the halfway point in this **deeply nested** example

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 10 object

level11.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 11)

Level11.description: The eleventh level in the nested structure, continuing the deep reference pattern

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 11 object

level12.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 12)

Level12.description: The twelfth level in the nested structure, demonstrating how schemas can be linked in a long chain

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 12 object

level13.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 13)

Level13.description: The thirteenth level in the nested structure, showing how *reference chains* can extend to arbitrary depths

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 13 object

level14.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 14)

Level14.description: The fourteenth level in the nested structure, continuing the demonstration of deeply nested references

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 14 object

level15.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 15)

Level15.description: The fifteenth level in the nested structure, approaching the end of this **extremely deep** reference chain

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 15 object

level16.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 16)

Level16.description: The sixteenth level in the nested structure, continuing the demonstration of schema reference capabilities

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 16 object

level17.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 17)

Level17.description: The seventeenth level in the nested structure, showing how OpenAPI can handle *extremely deep* hierarchies

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 17 object

level18.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 18)

Level18.description: The eighteenth level in the nested structure, approaching the final levels of this deep reference chain

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 18 object

level19.description: Reference to the next level in the nested structure (level 19)

Level19.description: The nineteenth level in the nested structure, the penultimate level in this **deeply nested** example

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 19 object

level20.description: Reference to the final level in the nested structure (level 20)

Level20.description: The twentieth and final level in the nested structure, demonstrating the maximum depth of this example

id.description: Unique identifier for this level 20 object

finalValue.description: The terminal value at the end of this deep reference chain, representing the actual data at the deepest level

NullableObject.description: An object that can be either a valid object with properties or `null`, demonstrating OpenAPI's support for nullable types

id.description: Unique identifier for the object when it's not null

name.description: Name or title associated with this object

description.description: Detailed text description providing additional information about the object. This field can contain *formatted text* for better readability.

TupleArray.description: A tuple array with fixed position types using prefixItems. This demonstrates how to create arrays with a **specific structure** where each position contains a predetermined type.

prefixItems.description: First element - always a string, typically used for identifiers or names
Second element - always a number, can represent quantities, measurements, or scores
Third element - always a boolean, useful for flags or toggle states
Fourth element - a complex object with its own structure and properties

id.description: Unique identifier for the nested object

value.description: Numeric value associated with this object

prefixItems.description: Fifth element - an array of strings, useful for tags, categories, or other collections

items.description: Individual string item within the nested array

MixedArray.description: An array with both prefixItems and items schemas, demonstrating a *hybrid approach* to array definition. This combines fixed position elements at the beginning with variable additional elements of the same type.

prefixItems.description: First element - always a string identifier that uniquely identifies the entire array data structure
Second element - user metadata containing basic information about the user associated with this data

role.description: Access level or permission role assigned to this user, controlling what operations they can perform

items.description: Additional elements - data entries that can appear in any quantity after the fixed prefix items. Each represents a **discrete data point** with timestamp and value.

timestamp.description: When this data point was recorded or created, in ISO 8601 format

value.description: The numerical measurement or quantity associated with this data point

tags.description: Categorization labels attached to this data point for filtering and organization

id.description: Unique identifier for the request, used for tracking and reference purposes

timestamp.description: When the request was created, in ISO 8601 format with timezone information

data.description: The main data payload that can be one of several types, using the **oneOf** discriminator pattern to support multiple object structures

oneOf.description: User data structure for operations related to user management and authentication. This option is used when the request is focused on user operations.

type.description: Discriminator field that identifies this as a user data object

user.description: User information containing personal details and account information

id.description: Unique identifier for the user account

name.description: Full name of the user as displayed in the interface

email.description: Email address associated with the user account, used for communications and *account recovery*

oneOf.description: Product data structure for operations related to inventory management and product catalog. This option is used when the request is focused on product operations.

type.description: Discriminator field that identifies this as a product data object

product.description: Product information containing details about an item in the catalog

id.description: Unique identifier for the product in the catalog

name.description: Display name of the product as shown to customers

price.description: Current price of the product in the default currency (USD), with **tax excluded**

inStock.description: Indicates whether the product is currently available for purchase

oneOf.description: Order data structure for operations related to purchase transactions and order management. This option is used when the request is focused on order processing.

type.description: Discriminator field that identifies this as an order data object

order.description: Order information containing details about a purchase transaction including line items and totals

id.description: Unique identifier for the order in the system

customer.description: Information about the customer who placed the order. This field is nullable for guest checkout scenarios.

items.description: List of products included in this order, with their quantities and pricing. Each item represents a **line item** in the order.
Individual line item in the order representing a specific product and quantity

productId.description: Reference to the product being ordered, linking to a product in the catalog

quantity.description: Number of units of this product included in the order, must be at least 1

unitPrice.description: Price per unit at the time of purchase, which may differ from the *current catalog price* if prices have changed

totalAmount.description: Total monetary value of the order, calculated as the sum of (quantity Ã— unitPrice) for all items

metadata.description: Additional metadata that can include any combination of these fields using the *anyOf* schema pattern. This allows for flexible metadata combinations where one or more of these objects can be included.

anyOf.description: Source information indicating where the request originated from

source.description: Source of the request, such as the platform or channel that initiated it (e.g., web, mobile, API)

anyOf.description: Priority information indicating the importance level of this request

priority.description: Priority level that determines how urgently this request should be processed. **High** priority requests should be handled before others.

anyOf.description: Categorization information using tags to classify the request

items.description: Individual tag value used for filtering and categorization

tags.description: Tags for categorization and filtering of requests. Multiple tags can be applied to enable complex filtering scenarios.

id.description: Unique identifier for the response that can be used for tracking and debugging purposes. This correlates with the request ID.

status.description: Overall status of the operation indicating whether it succeeded, partially succeeded, or failed. This field helps clients quickly determine the outcome without parsing the entire response.

result.description: The result data with nested oneOf and anyOf patterns, providing a **flexible response structure** that can adapt to different scenarios and operation outcomes.

oneOf.description: Success result indicating that the operation completed successfully. This structure is returned when the request was processed without errors and contains the requested data.

type.description: Discriminator field that identifies this as a success result object

data.description: The actual data returned by the successful operation, which can be one of several types using the *anyOf* pattern

oneOf.description: Error result indicating that the operation failed. This structure is returned when the request could not be processed due to validation errors, business rule violations, or system issues.

type.description: Discriminator field that identifies this as an error result object

error.description: Detailed error information explaining what went wrong and why the request failed

code.description: Machine-readable error code that uniquely identifies the type of error for programmatic handling

message.description: Human-readable error message explaining the issue in a way that can be displayed to users

details.description: List of specific validation errors or issues that caused the request to fail. This provides **actionable feedback** for correcting the request.

items.description: Individual error detail for a specific field or validation issue

field.description: Path to the field that has the error, using dot notation for nested objects

issue.description: Description of what's wrong with this specific field's value and how to fix it

metadata.description: Additional metadata with anyOf pattern, providing supplementary information about the response. This allows for *flexible combinations* of metadata fields to be included based on the context.

anyOf.description: Performance information about how long the request took to process

processingTime.description: Time taken to process the request in milliseconds, useful for performance monitoring and optimization

anyOf.description: Infrastructure information about where the request was processed

region.description: Server region that processed the request, indicating the geographic location of the data center

anyOf.description: Version information about the API that processed the request

version.description: API version number that handled this request, following **semantic versioning** format (major.minor.patch)

error.description: Container for all error-related information, keeping error details organized in a consistent structure

code.description: Machine-readable error code that uniquely identifies the type of error. Applications can use this for programmatic error handling and localization.

message.description: Human-readable error message that explains what went wrong in a clear, concise manner. This is suitable for displaying to end users.

details.description: Detailed breakdown of specific validation or processing errors, particularly useful for forms with multiple fields that need correction. This array may contain *multiple error items* for different fields.

items.description: Individual error detail for a specific field or validation issue

field.description: Path to the field that has the error, using dot notation for nested objects (e.g., `data.user.email`)

message.description: Specific error message for this field explaining what's wrong and how to fix it. This should be **clear and actionable**.
message.example: Must be a valid email address

details.message: Must be a valid email address
Must be one of: low, medium, high
